Text.Name: MJ Title
Text.Text: Solar Farming

Text.Name: MJ Title/Summary
Text.Text: They say there's no such thing as a free lunch, but near the sun there's something pretty close: solar energy farming.

Text.Name: Reactor Data/The Principles
Text.Text: The Principles

Text.Name: Reactor Data/The Principles/Power
Text.Text: The closer an object is to the sun, the more compact the sun's rays are and the more dense the solar energy. Halving the distance to the sun quadruples the amount of energy a solar panel can collect - doubled for both the length and the width of the panel.

Text.Name: The Implications
Text.Text: Implications

Text.Name: The Implications/Power
Text.Text: Build solar farms extra close to the sun for high yields and use beamed power relays to gain significant maintenance free energy elsewhere in Kerbin's solar system. A farm in a one billion-meter orbit yields 169 times the solar power compared one to in orbit of Kerbin - over 1 MW of energy per Gigantor XL! (Don't forget the radiators!)

Text.Name: Heading
Text.Text: Resources

Text.Name: Heading/Text
Text.Text: KSPI-E provides numerous additional resources over the stock version of KSP, extending numerous gameplay systems and adding a few new systems of its own.

Text.Name: MJ Title
Text.Text: Reactor Efficiency

Text.Name: MJ Title/Summary
Text.Text: Reactors require great care in order to be effective, as they can overheat and lose output efficiency.

Text.Name: Reactor Data/Core Efficiency
Text.Text: Core Temperature

Text.Name: Reactor Data/Core Efficiency/Power
Text.Text:
The reactor seen here has a core temperature of 16000K, which is rather high. As the reactor's heat is converted into power and propulsion, it continues to output more heat in order to reach this temperature.
If the ship cannot keep its temperature below the reactor's core temperature, the reactor will overheat and no longer be able to produce energy. Wernher would probably be more worried about the ship itself overheating with this particular reactor.

Text.Name: Reactor Data/Reactor
Text.Text: Efficiency

Text.Name: Reactor Data/Reactor/Power
Text.Text: The more heat a ship is able to effectively use and radiate away, the more MW the ship is able to produce as output. Reactors with high core temperatures are less susceptible to losing efficiency from overheating but generally produce enough energy for the ship to overheat without many radiators.

Text.Name: Heading
Text.Text: KSP Interstellar - Extended: An Overview

Text.Name: Heading/Summary
Text.Text: KSPI-E adds numerous additional techs, parts, and resources with a vision of providing a realistic road to the stars, beginning with technologies that could have been available in the 1970s/1980s up to techno- logies currently under real-world study and development. Some of these may or may not remain in the realm of science fiction but are theoretically sound to the best of our current scientific knowledge.

Text.Name: Image: Power/Sub-Heading
Text.Text: Reactors!

Text.Name: Image: Power/Sub-Heading/Power
Text.Text: Why rely on solar power when you can go nuclear and further beyond? Space is vast, and so are the power requirements involved. When conventional fuels aren't dense enough for an efficient launch, thermal and electrical engines step up to the plate. The heat from these reactors is equally useful for propulsion and for electricity, but the conversion rate isn't perfect and excess heat must be dealt with carefully.

Text.Name: Image: Relays/Sub-Heading
Text.Text: Relays!

Text.Name: Image: Relays/Sub-Heading/Resources
Text.Text: When even on-board reactors become impractical, there are yet more alternatives. Relays can send energy among ships and stations, allowing centralized reactors and solar farms to remotely 'fuel' low-mass ships with extreme thrust-weight efficency. Relays do have their limits however; the beamed energy must remain in focus to be received effectively, and the process of beaming power comes with its own costs.

Text.Name: Image: ISRUs/Sub-Heading
Text.Text: Resources!

Text.Name: Image: ISRUs/Sub-Heading/Resources
Text.Text: Ore is hardly the only useful thing available to a space program when travelling the cosmos. Solar winds leave regolith deposits on airless worlds, and rare metals and metals are often ripe for the picking. Uranium for fission and hydrogen for fusion can be found across the cosmos and harnessed. Take care, however - many useful processes leave by-products that require special handling!

Text.Name: MJ Title
Text.Text: Megajoules

Text.Name: MJ Title/Summary
Text.Text:
Reactors produce energy measured in Megawatts (MW), one of which equals 1000 units (or, one Megajoule) of Electric Charge per second. Large ones push into the Gigawatts range!
Electrical Charge can be converted to Megajoules with Capacitors, and Megajoules automatically convert to Electric Charge whenever a vessel runs low on energy.

Text.Name: Reactor Data/Power Production
Text.Text: Power Production

Text.Name: Reactor Data/Power Production/Power
Text.Text: The reactor seen here produces 3.0 GJ (or, 3000 MJ) of energy per second for a Deuterium-Tritium reaction: 3.0 GW x 1.00 for the power multiplier. 20% of that is output as charged particles, and the rest is emitted as thermal heat energy.

Text.Name: Reactor Data/Efficiency
Text.Text: Efficiency

Text.Name: Reactor Data/Efficiency/Power
Text.Text: The max rate for charged particle conversion is around 90% while the max rate for thermal energy is about 64%. Nearly 920 MJ of energy turns into waste heat if converting to MJ of electricity!

Text.Name: Heading
Text.Text: This is a test KSPedia page!

Text.Name: Heading/Text
Text.Text: Hello World!

Text.Name: Heading
Text.Text: Data Charts

Text.Name: Heading/Text
Text.Text: This section is devoted to data charts for KSP Interstellar Extended.

Text.Name: Heading
Text.Text: Harnessing the Future

Text.Name: Heading/Summary
Text.Text: Fission, fusion, and antimatter reactors provide opportunities for immense power generation.

Text.Name: Converter-Reactor Set/Charged Converter
Text.Text: Charged Particle Converter

Text.Name: Converter-Reactor Set/Charged Converter/Power
Text.Text: Converts an adjacent reactor's charged particle output into electrical power with higher efficiency than is possible with heat. Some engines can use charged particles for propulsion instead.

Text.Name: Converter-Reactor Set/Reactor
Text.Text: Reactors

Text.Name: Converter-Reactor Set/Reactor/Power
Text.Text: Power reactors operate by converting fuel into immense amounts of heat, with some also producing charged particles.

Text.Name: Converter-Reactor Set/Thermal Converter
Text.Text: Thermal Converter

Text.Name: Converter-Reactor Set/Thermal Converter/Power
Text.Text:
Converts an adjacent reactor's heat output into electrical power. The efficiency isn't perfect, so significant amounts of waste heat will be generated. Make sure to bring some radiators!
Some engines can directly use thermal energy for propulsion if attached directly to the reactor instead of a thermal converter.
